document.title: Idioms as Cultural Commonplaces: Corporeal Lessons from Hokkien Idioms

author.institution: University of Texas at San Antonio

document.abstract: This essay uses idioms, especially Hokkien idioms, to counter the western predisposition of separating mind and body, arguing that they underscore the mind-body shift that occurs with the acquisition of academic discourses.
document.publication-title: The Journal of the Assembly for Expanded Perspectives on Learning

field.value: Sue Hum is Assistant Professor of English at University of Texas at San Antonio. Her research and teaching interests include composition theory and pedagogy, modern rhetorical theory, multicultural and contrastive rhetoric, cultural studies and popular culture, and post-colonial gender theories. Drawing on her experiences as a Malaysian Chinese teaching in American institutions, Humâ€™s recent publications focus on the intersections among identity politics, materiality, and composition theory; she has published in JAC: Journal of Advanced Composition, Style, Journal of Curriculum Theorizing, and Readerly/Writerly Texts.
